Title: Which keyword is used to define a class in C#?
QuestionText: In C#, which keyword is used to declare a new class?
Explanation: The 'class' keyword is used to declare a new class in C#.

Title: Which of the following is a value type in C#?
QuestionText: In C#, which of the following types is a value type?
Explanation: int is a built-in value type in C#, while string, object, and dynamic are reference types.

Title: Which keyword is used to implement an interface?
QuestionText: In C#, which keyword is used when a class implements an interface?
Explanation: The ':' symbol is used in a class declaration to specify base classes and implemented interfaces.

Title: What is the purpose of the 'using' directive?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the main purpose of the 'using' directive at the top of a file?
Explanation: The 'using' directive allows you to use types in a namespace without specifying the fully qualified name.

Options.Text: To define aliases for classes only

Title: Are strings mutable in C#?
QuestionText: In C#, once a string is created, can its contents be modified?
Explanation: C# strings are immutable. Any operation that appears to modify a string actually creates a new string instance.

Title: What does LINQ's Where method return?
QuestionText: In C#, when you call .Where(...) on an IEnumerable<T> using LINQ, what kind of value is typically returned?
Explanation: LINQ's Where returns an IEnumerable<T> that lazily filters the original sequence based on the predicate.

Title: What do 'async' and 'await' enable in C#?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the primary purpose of the 'async' and 'await' keywords?
Explanation: 'async' and 'await' enable asynchronous programming with tasks, making it easier to write non-blocking code while maintaining a synchronous style.

Options.Text: Parallel processing with multiple threads only

Title: What is the purpose of 'using' statement with IDisposable?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the main benefit of using the 'using' statement with an object that implements IDisposable?
Explanation: The 'using' statement ensures that Dispose() is called automatically, even if an exception occurs, which helps release unmanaged resources deterministically.

Options.Text: It prevents exceptions from being thrown
It automatically logs all method calls
It forces the object to be static

Title: What is an event in C#?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the primary purpose of an event member in a class?
Explanation: An event encapsulates a multicast delegate and exposes a way for subscribers to be notified when something happens, following the publisher-subscriber pattern.

Options.Text: To expose notifications to subscribers via delegates
To provide data-binding only in WPF

Title: What is an extension method?
QuestionText: In C#, what is an extension method?
Explanation: An extension method is a static method in a static class that is called as if it were an instance method on an existing type, using the 'this' modifier on the first parameter.

Options.Text: A virtual method that can be overridden
A static method that extends the behavior of existing types
A method that can only be used in partial classes
A method that runs at compile time

Title: What does the '?' annotation mean in nullable reference types?
QuestionText: In modern C#, what does adding '?' to a reference type (e.g., string?) indicate when nullable reference types are enabled?
Explanation: With nullable reference types enabled, 'string?' indicates that the reference may be null, and the compiler performs nullability analysis and warnings based on this.

Options.Text: That the type is a value type
That the reference may legally be null

Title: What is the difference between 'var' and 'dynamic'?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the key difference between 'var' and 'dynamic'?
Explanation: 'var' is implicitly typed but resolved at compile time, while 'dynamic' is resolved at runtime and bypasses compile-time type checking for member access.

Options.Text: var is compile-time, dynamic is runtime
dynamic is compile-time, var is runtime

Title: What does the 'lock' statement do?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the primary purpose of the 'lock' statement?
Explanation: The 'lock' statement ensures that only one thread can enter a critical section of code at a time by acquiring a mutual-exclusion lock on a given object.

Options.Text: It prevents exceptions inside the block
It serializes method calls at compile time
It enforces mutual exclusion on a shared resource

Title: What is a delegate in C#?
QuestionText: In C#, what does a delegate represent?
Explanation: A delegate is a type that represents references to methods with a particular parameter list and return type, enabling callbacks and event handling.

Options.Text: A reference type for storing constant values

Title: What is the purpose of generic constraints?
QuestionText: In C#, why would you add constraints (where T : ...) to a generic type or method?
Explanation: Generic constraints restrict the types that can be used as type arguments, enabling the compiler to allow certain operations (like new(), interface members) safely.

Options.Text: To restrict type parameters to types that meet certain requirements
To disable boxing for all value types

Title: What is the difference between Task and Thread?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the main conceptual difference between a Task and a Thread?
Explanation: A Thread represents an OS-level execution unit, while a Task represents a higher-level unit of work that may run on a thread pool thread and is managed by the Task Parallel Library.

Options.Text: A Thread is higher-level; a Task is lower-level
A Task is a higher-level abstraction of work scheduled on threads
Tasks cannot return results, threads can

Title: Which keyword is used to define a struct?
QuestionText: In C#, which keyword declares a value type structure?
Explanation: The 'struct' keyword declares a value type that is typically allocated on the stack or inline in containing types.

Title: What is an indexer?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the purpose of an indexer in a class?
Explanation: An indexer allows instances of a class or struct to be indexed like arrays, using the this[...] syntax.

Options.Text: To allow object instances to be indexed like arrays

Title: What are attributes used for?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the main purpose of attributes such as [Serializable]?
Explanation: Attributes add declarative metadata to code elements, which can be inspected at runtime via reflection or used by tools and frameworks.

Options.Text: To attach metadata that tools and runtime can read

Title: What is dependency injection primarily used for?
QuestionText: In C#, what is the main benefit of using dependency injection (DI) in an application?
Explanation: Dependency injection decouples object creation from object usage, improving testability, maintainability, and adherence to the SOLID principles.

Options.Text: To speed up the JIT compiler
To decouple components and improve testability

Title: Which keyword declares a block-scoped variable?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, which keyword declares a block-scoped variable?
Explanation: Both 'let' and 'const' are block-scoped, but 'let' is commonly used for variables that will be reassigned.

Title: What does '===' do?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, what is the main difference between '==' and '==='?
Explanation: '===' is the strict equality operator; it compares both value and type without performing type coercion.

Title: What is a closure?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, what is a closure?
Explanation: A closure is the combination of a function and its lexical environment, allowing the function to access variables from the scope in which it was created.

Options.Text: A function bundled with references to its surrounding state

Title: What does Array.map() return?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, what does the Array.prototype.map() method return?
Explanation: map() returns a new array containing the results of applying the callback to each element of the original array.

Options.Text: The same array, modified in place
A new array with transformed elements

Title: What is the default value of an uninitialized variable?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, if you declare 'let x;' and do not assign a value, what is x?
Explanation: An uninitialized variable has the value undefined.

Title: What is the event loop?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, what is the role of the event loop?
Explanation: The event loop continuously checks the call stack and the callback queue to determine what to execute next, enabling non-blocking I/O in a single-threaded environment.

Options.Text: It compiles JavaScript to native code
It coordinates task execution between call stack and queues

Title: What is prototypal inheritance?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, how does prototypal inheritance work?
Explanation: Objects can inherit directly from other objects via the prototype chain; property lookups traverse this chain.

Options.Text: Objects inherit directly from other objects via prototypes
It is not supported in JavaScript

Title: What does 'use strict' do?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, what is a main effect of enabling strict mode with 'use strict';?
Explanation: Strict mode changes semantics to be more secure and predictable, for example disallowing implicit global variable creation.

Options.Text: It enforces a stricter set of semantics, e.g., no implicit globals

Title: How do you create a Promise?
QuestionText: Which of the following is the standard way to create a new Promise in JavaScript?
Explanation: A Promise is created by calling new Promise(executor), where executor is a function with resolve and reject parameters.

Title: What does async/await simplify?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, what do async/await keywords primarily simplify?
Explanation: async/await simplify working with Promises by allowing asynchronous code to be written in a synchronous style.

Title: What is 'this' in an arrow function?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, how is 'this' treated inside an arrow function compared to a normal function?
Explanation: Arrow functions do not have their own 'this'; they capture 'this' from the surrounding lexical scope.

Options.Text: It always refers to the global object
It is dynamically bound on call
It is lexically inherited from the surrounding scope

Title: What does Array.filter() do?
QuestionText: In JavaScript, what does the Array.prototype.filter() method return?
Explanation: filter() returns a new array containing only the elements for which the callback returns a truthy value.

Options.Text: It returns a single accumulated value
It returns a new array of elements that match a condition
It sorts the array in place

Title: How do you parse JSON text?
QuestionText: Which function parses a JSON string into a JavaScript object?
Explanation: JSON.parse converts a JSON-formatted string into a JavaScript value.

Title: Which keyword defines a function in Python?
QuestionText: In Python, which keyword is used to define a function?
Explanation: The 'def' keyword is used to define a function in Python.

Title: Which of these creates a list?
QuestionText: In Python, which syntax creates a list?
Explanation: Lists are created using square brackets, e.g., [1, 2, 3].

Title: What is a list comprehension?
QuestionText: In Python, what is a list comprehension primarily used for?
Explanation: A list comprehension provides a concise way to create lists from iterables with an optional condition.

Options.Text: To create lists from iterables using a concise syntax

Title: What does *args represent?
QuestionText: In Python function definitions, what does *args typically represent?
Explanation: *args collects any extra positional arguments into a tuple.

Options.Text: A tuple of extra positional arguments
A dictionary of extra keyword arguments

Title: What does **kwargs represent?
QuestionText: In Python function definitions, what does **kwargs typically represent?
Explanation: **kwargs collects extra keyword arguments into a dictionary.

Options.Text: A dictionary of extra keyword arguments

Title: What is a generator?
QuestionText: In Python, what is a generator function?
Explanation: A generator function uses 'yield' to produce a sequence of values lazily, returning an iterator instead of computing all values at once.

Options.Text: A function that always returns a list
A function that yields values one at a time using 'yield'
A function that runs in a separate thread
A function that generates random numbers only

Title: What is a context manager?
QuestionText: In Python, what does a context manager (used with 'with') typically manage?
Explanation: Context managers manage resources, ensuring that setup and cleanup (like opening and closing files) occur reliably.

Title: What is the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL)?
QuestionText: In CPython, what is the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL)?
Explanation: The GIL is a mutex that allows only one thread to execute Python bytecode at a time, affecting CPU-bound multi-threaded programs.

Options.Text: A mechanism that prevents multiple OS processes
A lock that ensures only one thread runs Python bytecode at a time
A way to manage global variables in C

Title: How do you import a module?
QuestionText: In Python, which statement imports the 'math' module?
Explanation: The 'import math' statement imports the math module.

Title: What is the difference between list and tuple?
QuestionText: In Python, what is the main difference between a list and a tuple?
Explanation: Lists are mutable (can be changed), while tuples are immutable (cannot be changed after creation).

Options.Text: Lists are immutable, tuples are mutable
Lists are mutable, tuples are immutable

Title: What is metaprogramming with metaclasses?
QuestionText: In Python, what is a metaclass primarily used for?
Explanation: A metaclass is the class of a class; it controls how classes are created, enabling customization such as automatically adding attributes or methods.

Options.Text: To define new numeric types only
To control how classes are constructed

Title: What does 'if __name__ == "__main__"' mean?
QuestionText: In Python, why is 'if __name__ == "__main__"' commonly used?
Explanation: It ensures that some code runs only when the file is executed as a script, not when imported as a module.

Options.Text: To check if the script is run directly rather than imported

Title: How do you install a package with pip?
QuestionText: Which command installs the 'requests' package using pip?
Explanation: The command 'pip install requests' installs the requests package.

Title: Which method is the entry point of a Java application?
QuestionText: What is the standard signature of the main entry point method in a Java application?
Explanation: The entry point is a public static void main method with a String array parameter.

Title: Which keyword defines a class in Java?
QuestionText: In Java, which keyword is used to declare a new class?
Explanation: The 'class' keyword declares a new class in Java.

Title: What is the default value of an uninitialized boolean field?
QuestionText: In Java, what is the default value of a boolean instance field that is not explicitly initialized?
Explanation: Instance fields of type boolean default to false.

Title: What is the difference between '==' and 'equals' for objects?
QuestionText: In Java, how does '==' differ from the equals() method when comparing objects?
Explanation: '==' compares object references, while equals() typically compares logical equality as defined by the class.

Options.Text: == compares references, equals() compares logical equality

Title: What is an interface in Java?
QuestionText: In Java, what is an interface primarily used for?
Explanation: An interface defines a contract of methods that implementing classes must provide, enabling polymorphism and abstraction.

Options.Text: To define a contract of methods to implement

Title: What are checked exceptions?
QuestionText: In Java, what characterizes a checked exception?
Explanation: Checked exceptions must be either caught or declared in the method's throws clause at compile time.

Options.Text: They must be declared or handled at compile time
They are always subclasses of RuntimeException

Title: What is the purpose of the 'synchronized' keyword?
QuestionText: In Java, what does the 'synchronized' keyword do when applied to a method?
Explanation: The synchronized keyword ensures that only one thread at a time can execute that method on a given instance (or class for static methods).

Options.Text: It allows only one thread at a time to execute the method
It marks the method as deprecated

Title: What is a lambda expression?
QuestionText: In Java, what does a lambda expression provide?
Explanation: Lambda expressions provide a concise way to represent anonymous functions, often used with functional interfaces such as in streams.

Options.Text: A concise way to represent an anonymous function

Title: What does the 'final' keyword on a variable mean?
QuestionText: In Java, what does it mean when a variable is declared as 'final'?
Explanation: A final variable can be assigned only once; after assignment, its reference cannot be changed.

Options.Text: It can change only inside constructors
It cannot be assigned a value
It can be assigned only once

Title: Which collection allows duplicates and preserves insertion order?
QuestionText: In Java, which of these collection types allows duplicates and preserves insertion order?
Explanation: ArrayList preserves insertion order and allows duplicates.

Title: What is type erasure in Java generics?
QuestionText: In Java, what is 'type erasure' in the context of generics?
Explanation: Type erasure is the process by which generic type information is removed at compile time, meaning generic types are not preserved at runtime.

Options.Text: Removal of unused classes from bytecode
Removal of generic type information at compile time

Title: What does the 'static' keyword on a method mean?
QuestionText: In Java, what does it mean when a method is declared as static?
Explanation: A static method belongs to the class rather than a specific instance and can be called without creating an object.

Options.Text: It can only be called once
It belongs to the class, not instances

Title: What is a Stream in Java?
QuestionText: In Java, what does the java.util.stream.Stream API provide?
Explanation: The Stream API provides a high-level, declarative way to process sequences of elements with operations like map, filter, and reduce.

Options.Text: A sequence of elements supporting sequential and parallel aggregate operations

Title: Which package is imported by default?
QuestionText: In Java, which package is automatically imported into every source file?
Explanation: The java.lang package is automatically imported.

Title: What does TypeScript add to JavaScript?
QuestionText: Which major feature does TypeScript add on top of JavaScript?
Explanation: TypeScript adds static typing, enabling optional type annotations and compile-time checks.

Title: How do you annotate a variable's type?
QuestionText: In TypeScript, which syntax annotates a number variable 'x' correctly?
Explanation: The syntax 'let x: number = 5;' declares x as a number.

Title: What is a union type?
QuestionText: In TypeScript, what does the type 'string | number' represent?
Explanation: It is a union type, meaning a value that can be either a string or a number.

Options.Text: A tuple of string and number
A type that can be either string or number

Title: What is the 'any' type?
QuestionText: In TypeScript, what does the 'any' type signify?
Explanation: The 'any' type disables type checking for that value, allowing any operation without compile-time errors.

Options.Text: A strict type that accepts nothing
A type that can be assigned any value, with no type checking
A type used only for generics

Title: What is the 'never' type?
QuestionText: In TypeScript, what does the 'never' type represent?
Explanation: The 'never' type represents values that never occur, such as functions that always throw or never return.

Options.Text: A top type that matches all values
A bottom type indicating no possible value
A type for asynchronous functions only

Title: What is the difference between interface and type alias?
QuestionText: In TypeScript, which statement about 'interface' and 'type' is generally true?
Explanation: Both can describe object shapes, but interfaces can be extended/merged more naturally, while type aliases are more general (unions, primitives).

Options.Text: Only type aliases can describe object shapes
Interfaces can be merged and extended more naturally
Interfaces can describe unions, types cannot
They are completely identical in all cases

Title: How do you define a function type?
QuestionText: Which TypeScript syntax correctly defines a function type taking a number and returning a string?
Explanation: The syntax '(x: number) => string' describes such a function type.

Title: What does the 'readonly' modifier do on a property?
QuestionText: In TypeScript, what does marking a property as 'readonly' mean?
Explanation: A readonly property can be assigned only during initialization or in the constructor, and cannot be reassigned later.

Options.Text: It enables runtime immutability enforcement only

Title: What is generics in TypeScript used for?
QuestionText: In TypeScript, why are generics used?
Explanation: Generics provide a way to create reusable components that work with a variety of types while retaining type safety.

Options.Text: To create types that work with multiple types while preserving type information

Title: What do utility types like Partial<T> do?
QuestionText: In TypeScript, what does the utility type Partial<T> do?
Explanation: Partial<T> constructs a type with all properties of T set to optional.

Options.Text: It removes all properties from T
It makes all properties of T required
It makes all properties of T optional
It converts T to an array

Title: Which file extension is standard for TypeScript?
QuestionText: What is the common file extension for TypeScript files?
Explanation: The standard extension for TypeScript files is .ts.

Title: What does 'unknown' type represent?
QuestionText: In TypeScript, how does the 'unknown' type differ from 'any'?
Explanation: unknown is a safer alternative to any; you must perform type checks before using a value of type unknown.

Options.Text: It can hold any value but requires narrowing before use
It is only for async functions
